column2: Officers during the early years of the war of spanish succession focused more heavily on drilling the infantry to withstand sustained enemy fire.
column3: Il s'agit des premières fortifications qui utilisaient des matériaux et techniques d'ingénierie modernes. Cette amélioration permet de construire un nouveau type de fortification.
column4: Dies war die erste Befestigungsart, für die moderne Materialien und Ingenieurstechniken zum Einsatz kamen. Diese Anwendung gibt Ihnen die Möglichkeit, einen neuen Befestigungstyp zu bauen.

column2: Our battle strategy has evolved to improve infantry line formations onthe battlefield.
With our infantry now going up against the enemy in line formation our tacticians have developed ways into which they could increase their firepower through repeated volley fire.
With our volley fire technique perfected our officers at the national military academy have devised a way for our soldiers to fire two ranks per volley instead of the usual one.

Military tactics has again come under review. Our officers believe that improving upon infantry reload times and adopting a training program focusing on weapon handling we will be able to hit enemy lines before they come into range of ours.

Our generals have discovered that establishing a fixed battlefield command post at a central location toward the rear allows messengers to always know where the HQ is located. Saddle orders run more efficiently sent during battles.
Tactical training is now mandatory for all new officers joining the army. They will learn how to hold their regiments togeather under enemy fire and maintain rigid line formation.
If we enforce a strict code of conduct for our officers and also ensure that they come from proper aristocratic stock than our soldiers will feel they are being led by true leaders.
Draconian punishments have been adopted by our military. Soldiers are punished for the smallest of code offences. This will allow for greater discipline in the ranks. Officers are naturally exempt.
The generals of our country have devised new tactical manuevers to reduce casulties while increasing enemy losses.

All of histories greatest battles that are remembered are the ones in which a small force fought larger armies. Unfortunately those same small armies also went on to loose the battle which is why they are remembered. But they are remembered because of the glory they won, let us look back Thermopylae and Gaugamela for modern inspiration.
The establishment of a general war commission responsible for army revenue and removed control of the military from control by the estates to the direct command under the monarchy.

Strict enforcement of dress codes led to greater morale amongst soldiers who take pride of their appearance, even while under heavy enemy fire amidst the dense smoke of volley fire and the thundering roar of cannons in the distance.
For centuries gunpowder armies were recruited mostly from towns, but a reform recently signed into law allows for even the peasants to serve in the army and fight for their country.

By the mid-18th century, armies were better drilled and organised than they had been a century earlier. Our soldiers know this and will fight with more pride in their eyes knowing that our nation will rise to glory in years to come!
Non commissioned officers are now being used as trainers for new recruits entering the rank and file. Our soldiers feel confident of their wisdom and experience.
The generals have found new ways to reorganise the national army into a strict order of battle.
The order of battle has been reformed so that regiments develop an espirit d'corps.
Military marching even in peacetime allows our army to maintain their order and discipline so that when war does break out again they will be ready to fight.
Encouraging the rank and file to regard their service in the military as a patriotic duty to their country will boost morale.
Permanent NCO trainers have been established at rear area military field camps to train new recruits. This will improve the fighting effiency of our entire land army.
The officers have looked back at the glorious battles of antiquity and many style seek similar personal glory. This has led to more reckless behaviour but an improvement in overall morale.
We have reformed the system of purchasing officer commissions. Officers must serve strict tours of duty before returning home.
Our generals have learned new battlefield tactics.
We have learned new tactical delay strategies to keep larger armies from overwhelming our own forces before they have time to reorganise for an attack.

An ingenious formation has been developed to maximise infantry fire power while advancing on the enemy, it is called the column. We have also learned new heavier line formation tactics to deal with enemy columns.
Saddle orders have recieved renewed focus with commanders now able to prioritise orders and assign special couriers for specific assignments.
We have learned new ways to mobilise a national army.
An army marches on its stomach. Without food and supplies our soldiers will suffer attrition, we have discovered land supply convoys are the best solution to this dilemma.

The early 19th century brought about many improvements to military organisation. We have developed a more flexible military staff system to ensure that military leaders not the general are allowed to issue their own orders.
Improved training of our officers has allowed them to study the recent tactical developments and apply them to evolving battlefield situations.
Our regimental commanding officers are now trained to take the initiative on the battlefield.
We are now allowing the promotion of officers from the ranks not just the aristocracy. This has led to a professional officer class in our country.

Strategic doctrine has developed into two opposing schools, those who favour the offense and technical development who call themselves 'Clauswitzian' and those who support a focus on morale who call themselves the 'Jominians'.

Army academic training meant that to be come an officer it was no longer enough to be of gentile blood. You also had to attend a formal education which could at best be as good as any college. This was one of the most important causes behind the professionalization of the officers corps.
We have developed an advanced battlefield courier system allowing for the continuous issuing of orders on the move.
As the armies of the 19th century got larger they had to learn how to fight on a grand scale in a complex strategic environment.
Our generals have delegated power and responsibility to the divisional level while they focus on the overall campaign strategy.
Since our generals have delegated power and responsibility to divisional commanders they have had time to develop a system of mobile command posts rather relying on the traditional static HQ.

The grand age of pitched field battles is coming to an end. With the development of industrial technology standing campaigns are increasingly fought on a larger scale. Thankfully our generals have devised new ways utilise technology to our advantage.
The issuing of orders can now take place with the use of a telegraph. Strategic mobility is bolstered by this new age technology.

The grand battle plan has been replaced by strategic doctrine. Armies still fight in pitched battles but the emphasis is now on caputring strategic supply depots and using cavalry to scout and flank enemy positions.
As the industrial revolutions advances our armies are now able to inflict more casulties upon the enemy with new guns and artillery our industry supplies them with.
Nationalism and imperialism fuel our industry. Some of that excitement has rubbed of on our soldiers who gladly die for the empire.
We are entering a new age of industrial warfare. Our generals are developing proto-type plans for defending fixed positions and using engineers to fortify vulnerable points of the battlefield.
Our generals have learned new ways to deal with partisans and insurgents improving the efficiency of the militias.
The glory days of armies fighting in pitched battles is now over. Our generals are developing new defensive strategies.
Focusing on the defensive has allowed the military to rely on a clear defensive doctrine. This allows a small forces to defend key strategic provinces.
We have developed a Frontline Doctrine which allows our land army to focus on fighting across an entire region, rather than a province.

After the enemy had gone over the top and his offensive was ebbing this tactics meant preplanned counterattacks against gaps in the enemy line where advance had not been synchronized. These counterattacks could sometimes push back the enemy even further than is original attacking positions.

At this points the trenches grow to formidable systems of trenches with two or even three lines of defenses bolstered with concrete fortifications and machine gun positions. The scene was as captured from the 'Inferno' section of Dante Alighieris 'Divina Comedia'.
The historical interwar period allowed for more research into the efficient use of the division rather than the regiment in the overall strategic doctrine.

After the end of the First World War, the major powers had to re-evaluate their military strategies in light of the brutual lessons learned during the years of inconclusive trench warfare. One major school of thought that emerged focussed on the importance of using massed firepower, principally in the form of artillery, to overwhelm the enemy and literally blast a hole in their lines to facilitate an advance, while another school of thought suggested that the key to victory on the modern battlefield was mobility, so that friendly forces could maneouvre around enemy strongpoints to pursue the attack on more advantageous terms.

With the advent of aircraft, it was not long until the question arose of how they could be used in wartime. At first their primary use was for reconnaissance, but soon thereafter aircraft began to be used to bomb military targets, and to shoot down other aircraft. New ideas and concept had to thus be evolved in order to best utilize this new military weapon.
The styles of warfare in the 18th Century changed by way of new organizational approaches to fielding and maintaining a professional army.
We have improved the resolve of our infantry to hold their nerve while under fire.
We have improved the resolve of our infantry to hold their nerve while under fire.
We have improved the resolve of our infantry to hold their nerve while under fire.
We have improved the resolve of our infantry to hold their nerve while under fire.
We have improved the resolve of our infantry to hold their nerve while under fire.
We have improved the resolve of our infantry to hold their nerve while under fire.
We have improved the resolve of our infantry to hold their nerve while under fire.
The infantry are now equipped with an improved socket bayonet allowing for greater defence against cavalry.
The line regiments have been equipped with the latest in smoothbore musket technology and have been trained in the most modern drill techniques. Their rate of fire has increased.
We have improved the resolve of our infantry to hold their nerve while under fire and also regimental cohesion.
We have improved the resolve of our infantry to hold their nerve while under fire.
We have improved the resolve of our infantry to hold their nerve while under fire.
We have improved the resolve of our infantry to hold their nerve while under fire.
We have improved the resolve of our infantry to hold their nerve while under fire.
We have improved the resolve of our infantry to hold their nerve while under fire.
The line regiments of our army are now trained in the field of distance marching and the idea of the forced march, a tactic adopted from the classical world and the campaigns of the roman legions.
Infantry are now organised into smaller units down to the company level allowing for improved tactical flexibility while on the battlefield
We have improved the resolve of our infantry to hold their nerve while under fire.
We have discovered the square formation and advanced volley fire tactics
We have greatly improved the resolve of our infantry to hold their nerve while under fire.
The infantry are undergoing a military modernization process. We have improved the resolve of our infantry to hold their nerve while under fire.
We have improved the resolve of our infantry to hold their nerve while under fire.
Our land regiments will now benefit from an espirit d'corps mentality
Flintlock rifles were heavier than traditional muskets and slower to reload but their accuracy and firepower were greatly increased.
The land regiments of our army have finished their modernization process and will now hold their ground for longer
We have improved the resolve of our infantry to hold their nerve while under fire.
We have improved the resolve of our infantry to hold their nerve while under fire.
We have improved the resolve of our infantry to hold their nerve while under fire.
We have improved the resolve of our infantry to hold their nerve while under fire.
We have improved the resolve of our infantry to hold their nerve while under fire.
We have improved the resolve of our infantry to hold their nerve while under fire.
We have improved the resolve of our infantry to hold their nerve while under fire.
We have improved the resolve of our infantry to hold their nerve while under fire.
We have improved the resolve of our infantry to hold their nerve while under fire.

Earlier on training meant march training and basic drill, but at this point full units trained interoperationability out in the field acting as if their brigade or division was at a state of war. This training vastly increased combat performance of units.

The old rules said that a officer breaking an order of a higher officer was to be brought to court martial. This made decision-making very indecisive. At this point regulations said that an officer was to carry on the core idea of the order of his superior officer, but how was at his own discretion. Our regular army now functions efficiently when engaged with the enemy in battle.

Muzzle loaded rifles were common during the American Civil War and also the Franco-Prussian War. They were the last true infantry weapons of the gunpowder age before technology shifted to more industrial weapons such as the devastating maxim gun of the 1880s or the repeater carbines produced by the Springfield and Winchester companies.
At this point seperate signal detachments were added  to divisions and up vastly increasing their communication.
At this point a tactical innovation and development of both weaponry and defensive points allowed the armies to build arching points of fire that flexibly could cover the terrain effectively.
By using a staff system even at low echelon units it enabled the leader to give orders continuously and accurate.
Breech loaded rifles have increased the firepower of the army. Our infantry now fights more effectively with this technological achievement.

The wargames where staff training. It meant playing out a situation, a fictive war of conflict, and setting to staffs against eachother and training them in order writing, communications and planning. At some degree it also trained therit tactical and operational skill. The infantry now benefit from this advance.

We have invented the maxim machine gun, now the most powerful infantry weapon of the modern age. Developed in the 1880s and improved over the course of the next 20 years the machine gun is the defining characteristic of the horrors of industrialized warfare. Infantry now benefit from this advance.
When literate NCOs started to flock to the ranks the average quality of the units and the training of the soldiers increased.
By exessively training the NCOs in the field and with the equipment these not only became pioneers for the men, but also highly competent trainers of the smaller units.
By exessively training the NCOs in the field and with tactical situations these not only became the leaders of the men, but also the initiative takers in combat.
We have improved the resolve of our infantry to hold their nerve while under fire.
The introduction of working staffs at lower echelon units was a spin off from having an effective and functional General Staff. Soon all units had staffs that supported their leaders.

At this point fire power was vastly more powerful than movement and even the front stationed infantry units had to dig in to survive the superior fire power of enemy artillery. Soon lines of deep defensive lines filled sections of the front bringing stalemate to the front. These lines where given the name trenches.

By introducing gasmasks and a set of rules for how to wear the uniform when attacked by gas, and standard operation procedures for movement under gas attacks, the losses and and effects of gas was diminished.
We have improved the resolve of our infantry to hold their nerve while under fire.

For those armies that focussed on firepower, another crucial decision revolved around how that firepower was to be utilized. One possibility was to craft intricate and detailed plans that integrated artillery strikes on specific targets timed to end just as the main assault was launched, while another possibility was simply to mass together as much artillery as possible and bombard the enemy until he gave way.

For those armies that focussed on mobility, it was important to decide how precisely the army was to be mobile. One option was to use standard infantry forces, and to overwhelm the enemy when contact was made, while another option was to focus on specialized spearhead units, often with a mechanized component, that were best suited for mobility and could quickly exploit weaknesses in the enemy line.

The concept of denying the enemy access to the air above one's army was discovered early in the budding air war. Aircraft whose sole role was to engage and eliminate enemy aircraft found thier use well before their bomber cousins.

In a never ending cycle, advances in one area led directly to advances in other areas. Dedicated fighter aircraft, whose role is to engage enemy aircraft, gained advanatges from the same sources as bombers, and in repsonse to advances in bomber aircraft. New engines, better designs, improved sights, and improved guns, made these fighters among the deadliest things in the air.

Begining with the first pilot to drop a grenade on his enemy, the use of aircraft to deliver munitions to the enemy was acknowledged to be of great tactical and strategic value. To enhance and expand this ability, dedicated bomber aircraft were developed.

Advances in aircraft design, improvements to construction, and improved aircraft engines greatly enhanced the abilities of bombers to accomplish thier missions. Increased range, greater payloads, and better armoring all made bombers a much greater threat to combatant nations.

We have learned new ways to besiege forts. Using a system of tunnels below and trenches above our seige works will slowly screep forward until our artillery can be brought into maximum effective range.
At this point artillery and divisional pieces trained to move the barrage for more flexible battlefield movement of the infantry, but also to optimize the fire and create 'killing zones'.

By loading artillery ammunition with poisonous gas substance the the killing zones stayed lethal for long periods of time. It also decreased the movement capacity of the defending units and the protective ability of concrete fortifications.

The first tank, sometimes called barrel, was blessed with mixed success due to the unreliability of these first steel monsters. However, when they worked they could open up the front wherever they went.
By introducing divisional artillery and mortars down on battalion level. Units got better firepower much faster which was very important both in offensive and defensive.
At this point tanks are more reliable and used in smaller units to break holes in the line where stormtroopers and regular infantry could pour in and fight the enemy.

Experience in the Great War showed the value and usefulness of tanks. However, those that saw action tended to be a bit unwieldy in rough terrain, and not very mobile. Tankettes were the first in a long line of developments in tank technology, that allowed for greater speeds and better maneuverability.
By planning a system of depots in peace time, set in a chain, these could be turned into focus points of the supply flow in war.
Logistical calculations offer standard measurements of how much supplies and reinforcements a standards unit needed during a defined time period made it easier to plan for a war.
Depots were focus points for the wartime supply system, but a replenishment transport organization was needed to get bullets and toilettpaper out to the men.
By checking certain attributes as morale, how well feed the soldiers were, illnesses and wounds it was possible to check how efficient the unit would fight in the upcoming combat in advance.
By counting losses on both sides and turn the figures into a matrix it was possible to estimate losses in a upcoming combat in advance.
By coordinating units by communicating and sending orders by telegraph the operational speed of units and decision-making increased vastly.

By making statistical standard measurements of how much ammunition was needed give the right effect against a predefined size of enemy unit in a predefined square area combat became more cost efficient.

By having high ranking officers attending politicians and being experts in defense commissions etc the Army could easily have a strong influence over the political decisions concerning the defense and the security policy.

These tables categorized tasks, position, etc so that it was easy in peace time to place personnel into combat formations. During mobilization the process was sped up as it was easy to know which soldier was to go to what company.

In wartime an influential Army that had lobbied for their cause for a long time could get full control not only over the excecution of the war, but also over the resource management of the country. This could basically be called a Military Dictatorship governed by the General Staff.
By pre-planning mobilization all reserve units had set mobilization areas and time tables for getting equipment, boarding trains, and frontal marching routes. This sped up the mobilization vastly.

In a highly militarized society, or a normal society in war, often needed not only military-civilan cooperation boards on a local level, but sometimes most of the local government could be appointed officers. This meant not only a strong military control, but also that the power of the Army increased disproportionaly in comparison to other governmental agencies.
Battlefield destruction called for airpower to focus on the bombing of frontline enemy military units, in close co-operation with friendly assaults launched against those enemy units.

As technology advanced, particularly in terms of motorisation, new concepts needed to be applied to more traditional doctrines. Supply, always an issue to an army, was greatly enhanced by these changes. It was now possible, as well as necessary, to establish major supply depots, from which entire sectors could be supplied. It was no longer necessary for long supply trains to feed frontline units, as centralised depots could rapidly dispense needed material to units.

Strategic destruction called for airpower to focus on the bombing of enemy cities and factories, in order to not only destroy the enemy's ability to produce the weaponry of war, but also to break the will of the enemy populace, thus leading to increased pressure on the enemy government to surrender.

Wile philopshy and the sciences were developing in new directions, one aspect of intellectual life remained fairly constant. This was classicism, the harking back for literary and artistic models, to the classics of ancient Rome and Greece.
Almost every enlightened person of the 18th century entertained an admiration for classical antiquity and like humanism of the renaissance could see no good in the culture of the middle ages.
The humanist movement during the renaissance of 300 years ago provided the right cultural background for the development of classicism in the 18th century.

Anyone who aspired to be enlightened did so through a rational understanding of classical literature. All the universities of Europe taught Latin and Greek and this had a great impact on mid-century writers.
The most estimable politicans and monarchs were those well versed in the classics and who understood the discourses of Demosthenes or Cicero.
The influence of classicism upon art and literature was profound and abiding. Indeed, the dominant aesthetic style of the 17th century continued relatively unchanged into the 18th century.
Baroque architecture was grandiose and inspired by the classical columns and arches of greece and rome.
The development of rococo architecture and aesthetic style first arrived in France but quickly spread to other parts of Europe.
In Europe several architects about the middle of the 18th century began to react against rococo developments of baroque art and to turn from grandiose models of antiquity to simpler classical models.
During the arcitectural revolution and changes made to grandiose design the basic underlying philopshy remained classical but was less ornamental.
As classicism dominated architecture, so a classically inspired elegance characterized the house furnishings and the personal adornments of polite society.
Every gentleman and lady aspired to be a patron of the arts and to surround themselves in elegance.
Conventional elegance led to crystal chandeliers and flashing mirrors of graceful mahogany furniture as well as delicatly chinaware from the manufacturies at Sevres, Dresden and Wedgewood.

In 1690 appeared John Locke's Essay Concerning Human Understanding. In this new work, a profound psychological study, he reached the conclusiont that knowledge is the discernment of agreement and disagreement, either of our thoughts or between our thoughts.

The philopsher David Hume, a scottish student of history and economics as well as of natural philosophy, maintained that thought is merely a practical instrument for convenient interpretation of our human experience, "it has no objective or metaphysical validity of any kind".

The philopshies of David Hume ended in the realisation for european philopshers that it is impossible to establish the reasonableness of God or religion, and the proper sphere of human thought is merely human experience.

Baruch Spinoza was of great influence to later 18th century philopshers struggling with Cartesian dualism. Spinoza did not follow Hobbes in reducing everything down into matter, instead advocating the idea that everything is both body and spirit.

Substance and nature, nature and God are identical concepts. This was the essence of Spinoza's philosophy of pantheism, and to it was attached the corollary that free will is an illusion of consciousness.

Naturalism substituted the supernatural with the natural law inherent to all things. Science and an advanced understanding of philophy replaced theology in learning institutions, colleges, academies and universities across 18th century europe.
Humanitarianism led to the tender regard for all human life and the defence and preservation of the natural rights and blessings of all individuals.

In the light of new developments in the field of metaphysics, a branch of 18th century philosphy, a good deal of criticism was indulged. The critique of knowledge allowed ideas to be tested through peer review which quickly caught on in other research fields such as the sciences. Belief or religious faith which had for 1000 provided answers to compelx problems was no longer enough. All theory had to be tested and either proven or refuted.

Institutions and practices of the 'enlightened' were dissected by rational theorists. In the areas of religion, politics, society and law, traditional ways of doing things were put to the test, improved or abandoned entirely, at least in academic discussion since real political action would take place in future decades via revolution.

The rational mind concept allowed greater thought on the purpose of philopshical study, was it to promote understanding of natural law, or was it to 'enlighten' subjects of the realm which for centuries had lived in ignorance and medieval superstition?

There were advances made during the 18th century regarding the rediscovery of the classics. Educated men and also women of the middle and upper classes recieved a classical education so as to develop their rational and scientific minds. Innovation rather than narrow sighted views of the world prevailed.
The critique of knowledge led to the advancement of the idea in a critcal spirit which allowed new ideas to flourish and be put to the test on the battlefield of ideas and rational philosophy.

Last of the major philopsher of the englightenment was Immanuel Kant. Grandson of a scottish immigrant in Prussia he spent his entire life in Konigsburg and like all educated men of the 18th century was interested in natural science, physics, law and geography. In his extensive philosophical writings he grappled with the problem of how to base moral duty on natural science rather than on religion.

The Kantian solution to the problem of rationalism vs religion was a new concept called idealism - the doctrine that while we cannot know that God exists, our moral sense requires us to recognize the transcendental existence of God and likewise the freedom of the will and the immortality of the soul.
If the conception of natural science in Hume's mind meant truth without God, in Kant's mind it meant God without certain truth.

The enlightenment originating in the natural order of the scientists, was reflected and broadened by speculation of contemporary philosophers. One of the earliest and most influentia of these was Rene Descartes, a frenchman by birth, who travelled all across Europe. His fame made when he published the Discourse on Method in 1637 and later the Principles of Philopshy in 1644. The Cartesian philosophy was a radical departure from the scholastic philosophy of earlier times. It distinguished sharply between soul and body, between mind and matter.

The Cartesian method established that the mind and soul have an immaterial existence of their own, but body and matter are alone suscepitble to scientific observation and hence subject to "natural law".

Descartes' philophy left no room for the supernatural in his understanding of the world. The idea that the laws of nature also govern men gave later 18th century political theorists profound insights into government systems, especially the theory of royal absolutism.

The radical ideas of the Englishman Thomas Hobbes' basic materialist philosophy strengthened royal absolutism. All nature, to him, was a machine. Unlike Descartes he admitted no dualism, but insisted that in the human mind and soul there was matter and motion.

Autocratic political practice during the 18th century was justified by reference to need for a Leviathan or soveriengn authority within the state which binds all men to its will and keeping them in awe of a common power. Without a common power or sovereign, absolutists argued, society would collapse and men would return to a state of nature or war of all against all and live out the rest of their lives in a nasty and brutish existence.

Heated religious partisanship between catholic and protestant religions had been the main feature of the intellectual life of western europe in the 16th and 17th centuries. In the late 17th century and early 18th century, however, intellectual interests gradually shifted from supernatural religion to natural science and what is called the enlightenment.

Natural science was no novelty for 18th century "enlightened" intellectuals. It had been advanced by ancient greeks and medieval monks, and its subsequent sensational progress stemmed from early modern scientists such as Galileo, Copernicus and Harvey.
The novelty or inherent value of natural science was its extension and popularization and the philosophical speculation which proceeded it.

Where natural science had once been the vocation of intellectuals, in the early 18th centuryit now became a vocation of numerous curious persons and it was more rigoursly seperated from magic and superstition.
Kings and princes now patronised natural science and the middle and upper classes became 'science-conscious' and greatly interested in its advancement.
Interest in natural science was both reflected and promoted by the rise of new institutions such as 'scientific academy' and various royal societies across europe.

As a mathematician Isaac Newton invented infinitesimal calculus and established the binomial theorem. In mathematics he calculated tables by which future position of the moon among the stars could be predicted - a helpful contribution to navigaton. These discoveries and theorems as well as numerous others are collectivized as Newtonian Physics or Newtonianism and were a great help to the advancement of the sciences in the 18th century.
Newtonian Physics explained hydrodynmics, including the theory of the propagation of waves, and made many improvements in hydrostatics.

In the research field of Optics, Newtonian Physics showed tht the rainbow is caused by the decomposition of white light, and led to the early 18th century doctrine that the structure of light is essentially atomic.

In the realm of mathematics, Newtonianism established a wealth of mathematical evidence prvoving the law of gravitayion and stated that every particle of matter in the universe attracts every other particle with a force varying inversely as the sqaure of the distance between them and directly proportional to the product of their masses.
The law of gravity was a sensational and convincing explanation not only of how apples fall to the ground but of how the earth and other planets are held in their orbits about the sun.

The laws of gravity was detailed in the book, Principia published in 1687. Lagrange, the foremost mathematician of the 18th century described the principia as the greatest production of the human mind. The law of gravitation served to established the Copernican system of astronomical on a firm basis.
A number of useful inventions attended and aided the development of physical science. Optical instruments such as the telescope and miscroscope were constantly being improved.

Some early experimentation was conducted on electricity and electro-magnetism and in 1746 two professor of the University of Leyden invented the so-called Leyden jar for the storage and sudden discharge of electric energy.

If Newton was the father of modern physics than the father of modern chemistry was Robert Boyle who in 1660 set forth the law that the volume of gas varies inversely with the pressure. By the 1760s as the early industrial revolution got underway knowledge of this principle became invaluable to understanding steam power and combustion.

William Herschel, a musician by profession, a self taught mathematician was a most assidious observer of the heavens and a perfecter of the telescope, detected spots on the sun, mountains on the moon, and ploar snow on Mars.

In mineralogy there was steady progress on fossils which had been dug up, recorded and preserved. James Hutton, a scot who was in turn a lawyer, physicians, scientific farmer and student of rocks communicated a survey of his geological studies in 1785. Entitled, Theory of the Earth  he maintained that past changes in the earth's crust could be explained by those which are seen in process, and that changes occur over many countless centuries.

There was marked development of the biological and medical sciences during the 18th century. In medicine, Malphigi, a modest and industrious professor at the university of Bologna learned much from vivisection and the microscope by confirming the theory that blood circulates around the body through capillary arteries.

Advances in the knowledge of animals was stimulated by accounts of numerous overseas travelers during this period and also by the collection and classification of rare and strange beasts in various royal menageries across Europe.

Natural scientists began to discover that plants themselves had sexes, male and female. The swede Carl von Linne classified these sex organs during his wanderings among the laplanders in search of arctic plants.
The Blue Water School meant building navies that could contest control of the High Seas. They included many capital ships and smaller ships to defend them.
Speedy Maneuvering tactics meant using speed to maneuver into firing position at a point where the enemy hard time to hit the ship, and also to make a breaking maneuver at an optimal time.

The Brown Water School meant building navies that defended home waters intensively while raiding the secondary lines of the enemy. It relied on a more diverse mix of ships than the Blue Water School, but it was also more cost efficient as it needed fewer expensive capital ships.
The Offensive Attitude Doctrine meant finding and destroying the enemy High Sea Navy at any cost.
The defensive attitude meant having a High Sea Navy as a fleet-in-being and only fighting the ultimate battle as a last resort or as a great opportunity.
Standard Raider Group Doctrine enabled groups of ships to hunt and destroy in the sealanes.

With the advent of the modern all-big-gun battleship, not surprisingly many admirals focussed on the importance of concentrating as many such battleships together in a single main fleet as possible, with the objective of seeking out the enemy's main fleet and engaging them in a single decisive battle. In this view, the vital point of battle was to have the most and largest main armament, in order to batter the opposition into submission.
Big Ship Competitor Doctrine meant building very small capital ships, thus this meant a smaller ship with clearly oversized main armament.
Sealane Hunters meant building a version of the frigate that had good endurance and acceleration and that could hunt merchant shipping in the major sealanes.
Fast Ship Killer doctrine meant building a version that where faster than the fast, but lighter than the heavy.
